titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George Washington University COVID-19 collection, 2020-2021 RG0155
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-01-11 11:55:15 -0500.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

physdesc.extent: Contains video oral histories, images and other digital files.

did.abstract: This collection documents the experiences of the students, staff, faculty and community during the COVID-19 pandemic.
did.physloc: Records are stored on a web-accessible server.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection will be organized into series. There will be series for the web archives and social media; the student survey conducted by the University Archvies; and the material collected and donated by faculty.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: On March 13, 2020, the President of the United States declared a national emergency in response to the growing number of COVID-19 cases nationwide. George Washington University pivoted to online learning at that time. This collection is an effort to document and identify for future researchers how the University responded to the virus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection was created by the University Archivist and contains material collected by the Archives as well as by faculty.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This collection was partially harvested and archived through Archive-It and Social Feed Manager. The video files were transferred and donated by the person being interviewed.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: To the extent that he/she owns copyright, the donor has assigned the copyright in her works to The George Washington University; however, copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For activities that the researcher determines fall under fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. Please contact Special Collections if the copyright status of the materials you wish to reuse is unclear. Staff will provide additional information.

For re-use of materials in the collection not created by the donor, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights, determining if the intended re-use falls under fair use, and obtaining approval from the copyright holder if the intended use does not fall under fair use. For such materials, researchers do not need anything further from The George Washington University's Special Collections Research Center.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:

Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository. Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

did.unitdate: Harvested from the web starting March 12, 2020.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This series is open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Websites were captured using Archive-it and show the University's response and how it kept the community informed during the pandemic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: GW Campus Advisory alerts related to Covid-19. This is the main page of alerts; each individual page was also captured and is available.
This page was retired and replaced with coronavirus.gwu.edu.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Prevention information at GW in response to Covid-19.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Website for questions related to Covid-19 at the university.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Information on GW's response to Covid-19.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The university suspended all non-essential, GW-affiliated international travel for students, faculty and staff beginning in March to help protect members of our community from the global spread of COVID-19. As we continue to monitor the situation and based on guidance from our public health experts, we have determined that it is necessary to continue the suspension of all non-essential international travel until further notice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Updates put out by the University during Covid-19.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Main webpage for GWU's response to Covid-19. This became the site for coronavirus information in place of the Campus Advisories.

did.unittitle: Culture and the Coronavirus: A GW Documentary Project

physdesc.extent: 47 oral histories as well as photographs and videos.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This series is open for research unless otherwise noted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: All materials in this series are from the documentary project, run by GW American Studies professor Melani McAlister.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In collaboration between the GW Library and Melani McAlister, Professor of American Studies and International Affairs, these materials document the experience and responses of the George Washington University community to the COVID crisis, while also providing a showcase for humanities and social science research on the pandemic. The project includes two components: the collection of oral histories and archival materials, and a website of exhibits and scholarship that draws in part on those materials. Culture and the Coronavirus aims to document the social and political impact of the pandemic, including the impact of choices made by government, medical practitioners, individuals, and GW itself.

The project has assembled personal memories and reflections from a broad swath of the GW community--students, staff, faculty, and alumni. Over the summer of 2020, with a small amount of funding from the American Studies department, Professor McAlister directed a research team of three students who conducted interviews with 35 GW students and faculty. Further plans involve doing more interviews, focusing particularly on staff and alumni, along with collecting and documenting other kinds of materials: photographs, emails, and journal entries.
The work continued through 2021 and expanded to include other adminstrators and GW-related individuals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs captured by students when GW first went to virtual learning, after COVID-19.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Videos captured by students after GW went to virtual learning after COVID-19.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some materials are restricted; contact the Special Collections for more information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Beginning soon after the school went to online only and staff and faculty began working from home, the University Archivist began to collect the stories which document the GW community's experience during Covid-19.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: These materials were all collected by the University Archivist.

physdesc.physfacet: All responses to survey collected into single spreadsheet.
